{{Feminism sidebar}}'''Feminist poetry''' is inspired by, promotes, or elaborates on feminist principles and ideas.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/146073/poetry-and-feminism|title=Poetry and Feminism|last=Golden|first=Shyama|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 4, 2018}} It might be written with the conscious aim of expressing feminist principles, although sometimes it is identified as feminist by critics in a later era. Some writers are thought to express feminist ideas even if the writer was not an active member of the political movement during their era. Many feminist movements, however, have embraced poetry as a vehicle for communicating with public audiences through anthologies, poetry collections, and public readings. Formally, feminist poetry often seeks to challenge assumptions about language and meaning. It usually foregrounds women's experiences as valid and worthy of attention, and it also highlights the lived experiences of minorities and other less privileged subjects. Sometimes feminist poems seek to embody specific women's experiences, and they are often [[Intersectionality|intersectional]] registering specific forms of oppression depending on identities related to race, sexuality, gender presentation, disability, or immigration status. This has led to feminist writing journals like [http://sotospeakjournal.org/about-so-to-speak/ So To Speak] providing a statement of intention to publish the work of women and [[Genderqueer|nonbinary]] people in particular. Kim Whitehead states that feminist poetry has "no identifiable birth date," but there are a few key figures identified as early proponents of feminist ideas, and who convey their politics through poetry.{{Cite book|title=The Feminist Poetry Movement|last=Whitehead|first=Kim|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1996|isbn=|location=Jackson MI|pages=3, ix-x, xii, xv, xvi, xviii, xviii-ix}} The title of first feminist poet is often given to [[Sappho]], at least in part because she seems to write about female [[homosexuality]] in [[Ancient Greece]], a culture and time when [[lesbian]] sexuality was usually ignored or erased.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43477494|title=Reading Sappho : contemporary approaches|date=1996|publisher=University of California Press|others=Greene, Ellen, 1950-|isbn=9780520918061|location=Berkeley|oclc=43477494}}{{Cite journal|last=Jannerson|first=Deb|date=2011|title='ADVENTURES IN FEMINISTORY: SAPPHO'|url=https://www.bitchmedia.org/post/adventures-in-feministory-sappho|journal=Bitch Media|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Catalano|first=Gabby|date=|title=How This Historic Icon Influenced Feminist Writers Today|url=http://www.womensmediacenter.com/fbomb/how-this-historic-icon-influenced-feminist-writers-today|journal=Women's Media Centre|volume=|pages=|via=}} ==Feminist Poetry in Asia== [[File:Toru Dutt.jpg|thumb|Toru Dutt]] === Feminist Aspects of Sanskrit Writing === The beginning of works categorised as literature in India began with the [[Sanskrit]] term ''[[kāvya]]'', a discourse separate from science or from the purely oral, and specific literary style that included works thought to contain a kind of soulfulness.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/70701869|title=The language of the gods in the world of men : Sanskrit, culture, and power in premodern India|last=Pollock|first=Sheldon I.|date=2006|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520932029|location=Berkeley|pages=3, 16, 19, 126|oclc=70701869}} In this early period, men were often posed as poets, and women as a kind of muse, as in the tenth century explanation for the origins of Indian literary culture: Poem Man's wife ("Poetics") chases him across [[South Asia]] creating varying kinds of literature across the region. Poetry was certainly an important part of political cultural life in the [[Sanskrit]] cosmopolis, and some women contributed; for example the poet [[Rajashekhara|Rajasekhara]] tells of women in different regions who entertain with songs. The early civilisation of [[Khmer Empire|Khmer]] country in modern-day Cambodia cultivated a literature in [[Sanskrit]], and diverged from its neighbours in creating a strain of poetry from the fifth century to the thirteenth century in which women were a source of praise and admiration. Take for example the Mebon Inscription of [[Rajendravarman II|Rājendravarman]], which features eulogies for specific women of note, and which is, according to Sheldon I. Pollock, "without obvious parallel in South Asia," and may be related to "specific kinship structures in the region." === Nineteenth Century Feminist Poets in India === Early anglophone women poets in India blended native traditions and literary models from Europe.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/739722886|title=Anglophone poetry in colonial India, 1780-1913 : a critical anthology|last=|first=|date=2011|publisher=Ohio University Press|others=Gibson, Mary Ellis, 1952-|year=|isbn=9780821443576|location=Athens|pages=287–288, 294–297, 363–371|oclc=739722886}} Amongst these early feminists, the Dutt Sisters - [[Toru Dutt]] (1856-1877) and Aru Dutt (1854-1874) stand out, and are sometimes compared to the [[Brontë family|Brontë Sisters]] in England. The Dutt sisters came from a family of poets, including their father Govind Chandra Dutt, and their access to education was unprecedented. The mother of the family Kshetramoni Mitter Dutt along with all three children - Toru, Aru, and their brother Abju Dutt, had received an education in English, and to some extent, in the [[Bengali language|Bengali]] language. The family had a reformist bent, and some members had converted to Christianity. Both sisters visited England in the 1870s, and attended the higher lectures for women at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]]. Toru Dutt's poetry in particular has been labelled extraordinary, because her writing "created a new idiom in Indian English verse." Spanning the turn from the nineteenth to twentieth century, [[Sarojini Naidu]] (1879–1949) represents a figure for whom politics and poetry are intertwined. Like the Dutt Sisters, Naidu was allowed access to all the educational resources she desired, and she passed the [[University of Madras|Madras University]] matriculation examination at age 12. She came from a large and free-thinking family. Her father, [[Aghorenath Chattopadhyay]], was a well-regarded doctor, known for his educational reforms, and her mother, Barada Sundari Devi, was educated at a [[Brahmo]] school. Naidu had seven siblings all of whom made contribution to Indian life, for example her brother [[Virendranath Chattopadhyaya|Virendranath Chattopadhyay]] was an Indian revolutionary. Naidu studied at [[Girton College, Cambridge|Girton College]], Cambridge, which brough her into contact with writers of the day, including [[Arthur Symons]], and [[W. B. Yeats|W.B. Yeats]]. Ultimately, Naidu's unconventional upbringing and education were catalysts for her intellectual powers, since as she writes in her roman-de-clef 'Sulani,' ""Unlike the girls of her own nation, she had been brought up in an atmosphere of large un-convention and culture and absolute freedom of thought and action."{{Cite book|title="Sunalini," ms.|last=Naidu|first=Sarojini|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=British Library.|pages=EUr.A.95}} After her marriage to Govindarajulu Naidu - controversial because of his age and class - Naidu began publishing poetry to international acclaim, and in parallel with this literary art, she maintained her nationalist efforts, eventually becoming the first Indian woman to serve as president of the [[Indian National Congress]]. === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry === Anthologies were an important part of foregrounding women's writing in volumes like [[Eunice de Souza|Eunice De Souza]]'s ''Nine Indian Women Poets'' (1997).{{Cite journal|last=Bethala|first=Melody|date=February 2017|title='The battle is to validate the material': A brief history of Eunice de Souza's anthologies of Indian literature.|url=https://humag.co/features/the-battle-is-to-validate-the-material|journal=Honest Ulsterman|volume=|pages=|via=}} == Feminist Poetry in Central America and the Caribbean == [[File:Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz.JPG|thumb|Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz]] '''The Feminist Legacy of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz''' During the Latin American colonial period, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz (est 1651-1695) was a poet, dramatist, and nun.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/sor-juana-in%C3%A9s-de-la-cruz|title=Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|last=Cruz|first=Sor Juana Inés de la|date=2003-02-04|website=Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}} Exceptionally talented and intelligent, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz chose to spend most of her life in the Convent of the Order of St. Jérôme, and her response to a critical Bishop, ''Respuesta a Sor Filotea,'' is hailed as one of the first feminist manifestos. Not only did Sor Juana have to deal with the criticisms of men of her era, but she also faced the Spanish perception of literature from the colonies as second-rate.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/985840432|title=Routledge research companion to the works of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|last=Schlau|first=edited by Emilie L. Bergmann and Stacey|publisher=|year=|isbn=9781317041641|location=London|pages=xi|oclc=985840432}} Sor Juana's poems challenge the assumptions of men about women, for example in [https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/you-foolish-men 'You Foolish Men.']
What kind of mind is odder than his who mists a mirror and then complains that it's not clear.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/you-foolish-men|title=You Foolish Men|last=aapone|date=2010-06-07|website=You Foolish Men|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}}
The fact that she chooses to avoid a heteronormative life with marriage and children is often held up as a feminist choice, and she represents the possibility to be a woman who 'pursues knowledge and procreates only through art and not through a genetic legacy.'{{Cite book|url=https://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9780230104464|title=Femmenism and the Mexican Woman Intellectual from Sor Juana to Poniatowska - Boob Lit {{!}} Emily Hind {{!}} Palgrave Macmillan|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=34|language=en}} === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry in Central America and the Caribbean === Anthologies of women's writing in the 1980s foregrounded the importance of women poets in the Caribbean, for example in M.J. Fenwick's ''Sisters of Caliban'' (1996) described as "a gendered and racialized position of resistance".{{Cite journal|last=Lara|first=Irene|date=2007|title=Beyond Caliban's Curses: The Decolonial Feminist Literacy of Sycorax|url=https://vc.bridgew.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=1289&context=jiws|journal=Journal of International Women's Studies|volume=9.1|pages=97|via=}} ==Feminist Poetry in North America == [[File:Joy harjo 3271646.JPG|thumb|Poet Joy Harjo's argument for the centrality and importance of native poetry in North America is significant for feminist literary histories.]] === Early Feminist Poets in North America === Though they lived in an era before an organised feminist movement, certain American poets have been lauded by [[feminist literary criticism]] as early examples of feminist writers. Feminist poetry in the United States is often thought of as beginning with [[Anne Bradstreet]] (1612-1672), the first poet of the [[New World]]. There were also, however, native poetic traditions before colonialism, which continue to the present day, and represent an important strand of American poetry. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native]] traditional verse has included "lyrics, chants, anecdotes, incantations, riddles, proverbs, and legends."{{Cite book|title=A Preface to Colonial American Poetry: A Study in the Poetry of the Age in Relation to American History and Literature|last=Jabbar|first=Wisam Abdul|publisher=iUniverse|year=2005|isbn=|location=|pages=57}} While it is difficult to ascertain from these oral traditions whether the authors of early texts were male or female, precolonial native poetry certainly addresses issues relevant to women in a sensitive and positive way, for example the [[Seminole]] poem, 'Song for Bringing a Child Into the World.'{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/865473325|title=Native American songs and poems : an anthology|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Swann, Brian,|year=|isbn=9780486112138|location=Mineola, New York|pages=1|oclc=865473325}} In fact, native poetry is a separate but relevant tradition in the United States; as poet [[Joy Harjo]] comments, "The literature of the aboriginal people of North America defines America. It is not exotic."{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/144560/native-american-poetry-and-culture|title=Native American Poetry and Culture|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018}} In the context of Canada, Anne Marie Dalton argues that at least some indigenous communities in North America (though not all) have lived by practicing [[ecofeminism]] with regard to women's roles, and the sustainability of the land.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/671640200|title=The Cambridge history of Canadian literature|last=|first=|date=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|others=Howells, Coral Ann., Kröller, Eva-Marie.|year=|isbn=9780511862243|location=Cambridge|pages=78–80|oclc=671640200}} When colonialism did arrive, Anne Bradstreet was one of the first poets to win acclaim, and many of her poems are thought to have feminist themes. The mother of eight children, Bradstreet sometimes found herself in conflict with her domestic circumstances and her role as a [[Puritans|Puritan]] woman.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/anne-bradstreet|title=Anne Bradstreet|last=Martin|first=Wendy|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Feminist literary criticism defined Bradstreet in retrospect as a "protofeminist," because of her "gender awareness," and her treatment of domestic concerns of importance in women's lives.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/785576747|title=Feminist writings from ancient times to the modern world : a global sourcebook and history|last=|first=|date=2011|publisher=Greenwood|others=Wayne, Tiffany K., 1968-|year=|isbn=9780313345814|location=Santa Barbara|pages=106|oclc=785576747}} Poet [[Alicia Ostriker]] describes Bradstreet's style as "a combination of rebellion and submission," a pattern that Ostriker also sees in poets to come like [[Phillis Wheatley|Phyllis Wheatley]] and [[Emily Dickinson]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/92110/a-change-of-world-episode-1-the-wilderness|title=A Change of World, Episode 1: The Wilderness|last=Fox|first=Curtis|date=2018|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} [[Phillis Wheatley|Phyllis Wheatley]] (1753-1784) was brought to the United States from Africa as a slave, and sold to the Wheatley family of Boston in 1771.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/phillis-wheatley|title=Phillis Wheatley|last=O'Neale|first=Sondra A.|date=|website=Poetry Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} A prodigy as a child, Wheatley was the first black person to publish a book of poems in the American colony, and though her poems are sometimes thought of as expressing "meek submission," she is also what [[Camille Dungy]] describes as "a foremother," and a role model for black women poets as "part of the fabric" of American poetry. Involved in the abolitionist movement, Wheatley became "a spokeswoman for the cause of [[American independence]] and the [[Abolitionism|abolition of slavery]]."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/316827798|title=The right to write : the literary politics of Anne Bradstreet and Phillis Wheatley|last=Seidler.|first=Engberg, Kathrynn|date=2010|publisher=University Press of America|year=|isbn=9780761846093|location=Lanham, MD|pages=xvi|oclc=316827798}} Nineteenth century poet [[Emily Dickinson]] (1830-1886) is often thought of as feminist, though she never wrote for public audiences. Not necessarily recognized in her own lifetime, Dickinson offers powerful female speakers. Engaging with male writers like [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] or [[William Wordsworth]], her work is praised for developing "others ways of representing the position of a female speaking subject" in particular romantic and psychological dynamics.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/22490475|title=Dickinson and the boundaries of feminist theory|last=1958-|first=Loeffelholz, Mary,|date=1991|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=0252017897|location=Urbana|pages=22–25|oclc=22490475}} See for example the declaration of desire and longing in [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44087/wild-nights-wild-nights-269 'Wild nights - Wild nights!.'] In the 1970s, [[feminist literary criticism]] articulated Dickinson's feminism through groundbreaking studies by [[Margaret Homans]], [[Sandra Gilbert]] and [[Susan Gubar]], and Suzanne Juhasz. Critics point in particular to Dickinson's expression of anger at women's confinement, to her re-gendering of external and internal realities, to her use of feminist motifs, and to her articulation of her particular position in Puritan, patriarchal culture.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/185033031|title=Approaching Emily Dickinson : critical currents and crosscurrents since 1960|last=1943-|first=White, Fred D.,|date=2008|publisher=Camden House|year=|isbn=9781571133168|location=Rochester, N.Y.|pages=65–70|oclc=185033031}} Dickinson also proves that confinement to domestic life does not dictate an inability to create great poetry. As the poet [[Adrienne Rich]] writes, "Probably no poet ever lived so much and so purposefully in one house; even, in one room."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/4195229|title=Shakespeare's sisters : feminist essays on women poets|last=|first=|date=1979|publisher=Indiana University Press|others=Gilbert, Sandra M., Gubar, Susan, 1944-|year=|isbn=0253112583|location=Bloomington|pages=99|oclc=4195229}} ===Post 1900s North American Feminist Poets=== [[File:Alice Dunbar Nelson cropped.jpg|thumb|Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson]] Feminist poets of the early twentieth century harnessed the new opportunities and rights which came as a result of coeducational resources now afforded to women.{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/928779869|title=A history of twentieth-century American women's poetry|last=Kinnhan.|first=Linda|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=|oclc=}} Cristianne Miller goes so far as to say that 'In no period before and rarely since have women poets had greater success and influence than in the first half of the twentieth century in the United States.' Living through the turn of the century was [[Alice Dunbar Nelson|Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson]](1875-1935), a poet often thought of in relation to her marriage to [[Paul Laurence Dunbar|Paul Dunbar]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/alice-moore-dunbar-nelson|title=Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Dunbar-Nelson, however, is an accomplished writer in her own right, praised by poet [[Camille Dungy]] for breaking out of writing only about "black women's things," instead addressing "the theater and war of life." Born in New Orleans, Dubar-Nelson's family had a heritage of African American, Anglo, Native American, and Creole roots. [[Camille Dungy]] suggests that bringing black women writers like Dunbar-Nelson into the feminist canon alongside Bradstreet and Dickinson is of great importance in rediscovering literary foremothers for black women writers. The early twentieth century was also a significant moment for feminism, because it saw the rise of the [[Women's suffrage|suffragist]] movement, and poets responded to the political moment by writing poems regarding the debate as to whether or not women should have the right to vote. In her collection ''Suffrage Songs and Verses,'' [[Charlotte Perkins Gilman]] criticises wealthy women, who because they live a life of ease, deny other women their rights.{{Cite web|url=http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/gilman/suffrage/suffrage.html#anti|title=Suffrage Songs and Verses.|website=digital.library.upenn.edu|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Alice Duer Miller]] (1874-1942) wrote poems mocking [[Anti-suffragism|anti-suffragist]] advocates, which were published in the [[New-York Tribune|New York Tribune]], a popular news outlet of the era.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aliceduermiller.com|title=Alice Duer Miller|website=www.aliceduermiller.com|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2012/01/are-women-people-the-suffragist-poems-of-alice-duer-miller|title=Are Women People? The suffragist poems of Alice Duer Miller by Harriet Staff|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehairpin.com/2012/01/are-women-people/|title=Are Women People?|date=2012-01-19|work=The Hairpin|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}} While some poets have been embraced by the feminist canon, others are seen as awkward additions in spite of their success, for example [[Gertrude Stein]] (1874-1946) is often defined more as a poet involved in modernist experimentation than feminist discourse.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/gertrude-stein|title=Gertrude Stein|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Some of modernism's tenets seem incompatible with some kinds of feminism, like the repression of emotion, and avoidance of domesticity. Nevertheless, second wave feminists found modernist women poets like [[H.D.]] (1886-1961) to be a powerful example, unfairly overlooked by male critics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/h-d|title=H. D.|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} By the time of the 1940s, magazines were being set up which, though perhaps not obviously feminist, certainly in their practices were very different to male-run publications: take for example [[Contemporary Verse 2|Contemporary Verse]] (1941–52) published in Canada by a group of women writers, including [[Dorothy Livesay]], [[P. K. Page|P.K. Page]], and [[Anne Marriott]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/969538355|title=The making of modern poetry in Canada : essential commentary on Canadian poetry in English|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Gnarowski, Michael, 1934-, Dudek, Louis, 1918-2001,|year=|isbn=9780773549609|edition= Third|location=Montreal|pages=xxix, xxv|oclc=969538355}} ===Post 1960 North American Feminist Poets=== [[File:Audre Lorde.jpg|thumb|Audre Lorde]] Historian [[Ruth Rosen]] describes the mainstream poetry world before 1960 as "an all boy's club," adding that poetry was not "women's place," and explains that in order to get a poetry book published, writers would have to overcome their gender and race.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/101723/books-that-broke-down-barriers|title="A Change of World, Episode 2: Books that Broke Down Barriers"|last=Fox|first=Curtis|date=|website=Poetry Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The interest of American feminist poets in the rights of minorities have often put them in conflict with American institutions like the [[Academy of American Poets|American Academy of Poets]]. One of the strategies of feminist poets is to demonstrate "their opposition to a dominant poetry culture that does not recognize the primacy of gender and other oppressions". [[1960s]] feminist poetry provided a useful space for [[Second-wave feminism|second wave]] American feminist politics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/146073/poetry-and-feminism|title=Poetry and Feminism|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The poets, however, were not necessarily unified in their themes or formal techniques, but had links to specific movements and trends, such as the New York Poets, the [[Black Mountain poets]], the [[San Francisco Renaissance]], or the [[Beat poets|Beat Poets]]. [[Denise Levertov]] (1923-1997), for example, refined and built upon poetics from the [[Black Mountain poets|Black Mountain]] School.{{Cite journal|last=Levertov|first=Denise|date=1965|title=Some Notes on Organic Form|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/articles/69392/some-notes-on-organic-form-56d249032078f|journal=Poetry|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/denise-levertov|title=Denise Levertov|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Women like [[Sylvia Plath]] (1932-1963) and [[Anne Sexton]] (1928-1974) provided a feminist version of the [[Confessional poetry|Confessional Poets]]' poetics, which worked alongside feminist texts of the day, like [[Betty Friedan]]'s ''[[The Feminine Mystique]]'', to "address taboo subjects and social limitations that plagued American women" (although Plath died before ''The Feminine Mystique'' was published){{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2014/09/confessionalism-feminism-at-coldfront|title=Confessionalism and Feminism at Coldfront|last=Harriet|first=Staff|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/anne-sexton|title=Anne Sexton|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/sylvia-plath|title=Sylvia Plath|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Lucille Clifton]] (1936-2010) also borrowed from [[Confessional poetry|Confessional]] poetics, a strategy that was key according to [[Adrienne Rich]] for avoiding being trapped between "misogynist black male critics and white feminists still struggling to unearth a white woman's tradition."{{Cite web|url=http://coldfrontmag.com/confessionalism-birthed-from-feminism-jd/|title=Confessionalism Birthed from Feminism|last=Wilson|first=Merida|date=|website=http://coldfrontmag.com/confessionalism-birthed-from-feminism-jd/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/lucille-clifton|title=Lucille Clifton|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Confessional poetry|Confessionalism]] lent to feminist poetry the possibility of agency for the female speaker, and the refusal to present well-behaved women, though it was troubling that the Confessional women poets who committed suicide tended to be foregrounded and promoted in poetry circles. [[Muriel Rukeyser]] (1913-1980) was a generation older than Plath and Sexton, and rejected the suicidal poetics of the Confessional writers. Rukeyser also wrote frankly about the body and sexuality, inspiring later poets like [[Sharon Olds]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/144891/a-change-of-world-episode-4-a-place-of-permission|title=A Change of World, Episode 4 : A Place of Permission - Poetry Off the Shelf|date=2018-09-26|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-26}} In addition, Rukeyser's leftist politics and militant writing style proved to be a model for poet [[Adrienne Rich]]. Both poets also contributed to the [[Anti-Vietnam War Movement|anti-Vietnam War movement]]: for example [[Muriel Rukeyser|Rukeyser]] and [[Adrienne Rich|Rich]] took part in readings as part of the event series, the Week of the Angry Arts Against the War in Vietnam. [[Adrienne Rich]] (1929-2012) also became a key feminist poet, praised by [[Alicia Ostriker]] for bringing "intellect" to poetry, "something that women were not supposed to have," as well as "a leftward leaning sensibility in which coming out as lesbian was just one part."{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/adrienne-rich|title=Adrienne Rich|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Rich's [https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/diving-wreck 'Diving into the Wreck'] is an important feminist poem, as it describes moving down as an act of triumph, where the wreck might be history, literature, or human life, and the poem itself is a kind of "battlecry." Famously, when Rich received the National Book Award for her collection, ''Diving into the Wreck,'' she accepted it on behalf of all the female nominees, including [[Audre Lorde]] and [[Alice Walker]]:
We, Audre Lorde, Adrienne Rich, and Alice Walker, together accept this award in the name of all the women whose voices have gone and still go unheard in a patriarchal world, and in the name of those who, like us, have been tolerated as token women in this culture, often at great cost and in great pain. We believe that we can enrich ourselves more in supporting and giving to each other than by competing against each other; and that poetry— if it is poetry— exists in a realm beyond ranking and comparison. We symbolically join together here in refusing the terms of patriarchal competition and declaring that we will share this prize among us, to be used as best we can for women.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalbook.org/nbaacceptspeech_arich_74.html#.W5_7ri-ZN8c|title=National Book Awards Acceptance Speeches: ADRIENNE RICH, WINNER OF THE 1974 NATIONAL BOOK AWARD FOR DIVING INTO THE WRECK|last=Rich|first=Adrienne|date=1974|website=National Book Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018}}
[[Audre Lorde]] (1934-1992) was a feminist poet whose poetry and prose writings have had a great impact on feminist thinking to the present day.{{Cite web|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/culture/books/2017/09/feminist-lesbian-warrior-poet-rediscovering-work-audre-lorde|title=Feminist, lesbian, warrior, poet: rediscovering the work of Audre Lorde|website=www.newstatesman.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://frieze.com/article/what-audre-lordes-language-self-care-can-teach-us-after-metoo|title=What Audre Lorde's Language of Self-Care Can Teach Us After #MeToo|website=frieze.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/audre-lorde|title=Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Sometimes thought of as a writer who developed a "black lesbian eroticism," Lorde's poetry also shows a deep ethical and moral commitment, which seeks to challenge racism, sexism, and homophobia.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53315369|title=Warrior poet : a biography of Audre Lorde|last=1948-|first=De Veaux, Alexis,|date=2004|publisher=W.W. Norton|year=|isbn=0393019543|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=4|oclc=53315369}} Many of Lorde's poems have a great deal in common with the modern-day campaign [[Black Lives Matter|#blacklivesmatter]], as they pose questions about institutionalised racism in American public services like the price force, for example in her poem [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/53918/power-56d233adafeb3 'Power']:
A policeman who shot down a ten year old in Queens stood over the boy with his cop shoes in childish blood and a voice said "Die you little motherfucker" and there are tapes to prove it. At his trial this policeman said in his own defense "I didn't notice the size nor nothing else only the color". And there are tapes to prove that, too.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/53918/power-56d233adafeb3|title=Power by Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}
Lorde's work has also proved to be an inspiration to feminists working on the subject of feminist [[wikt:killjoy|killjoy]]s, and the trope of the angry black woman, often used as an excuse to belittle or reduce the impact of just concerns about racism.{{Cite news|url=https://www.guernicamag.com/sara-ahmed-the-personal-is-institutional/|title=Sara Ahmed: Notes from a Feminist Killjoy|date=2017-07-17|work=Guernica|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}} Lorde's poems often draw attention to the universalising tendencies of some white feminisms, so in a poem about a mythical woman, [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/42583/a-woman-speaks 'A Woman Speaks,'] only at the end does Lorde draw attention to the problematic universal, white woman, adding
I am woman and not white.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/42583/a-woman-speaks|title=A Woman Speaks by Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}
Lorde went on to be an effective and challenging teacher of other women poets, such as [[Donna Masini]]. === Feminist Anthologies in North America in the 1970s and 80s === In the 1970s and 80s, feminist poetry evolved alongside the feminist movement, becoming a useful tool for activist groups organised around [[radical feminism]], [[socialist feminism]], and [[lesbian feminism]]. Poetry readings became spaces for feminists to come together in cities and in rural communities, and talk about sexuality, women's roles, and the possibilities beyond heteronormative life. Figures like [[Judy Grahn]] were figureheads for the women's movement, providing electrifying readings that enlivened and inspired audiences. Often the poems were political, and sometimes the writers tried to use language that "ordinary women" could read and understand. Countering tokenism was also an important aspect of the feminist poetry project.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/143653/shattering-the-blue-velvet-chair|title=A Change of World, Episode 3: Shattering the Blue Velvet Chair - Poetry Off the Shelf|date=2018-09-26|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-26}} [[Carolyn Forché]] describes the "blue velvet chair" effect, inspired by group portraits of canonical poets, in which one - but only one - woman writer was allowed to join the men, often sat in a Victorian blue velvet chair. As poetry took on a new significance for the feminist movement, so a number of new poetry anthologies were published which emphasised women's voices and experiences.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/907585915|title=The Oxford handbook of Canadian literature|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Sugars, Cynthia Conchita, 1963-|year=|isbn=9780199941865|location=New York, NY|pages=853|oclc=907585915}} Anthologies played an important role generally in opening up the political consciousness of poetry, an important example being [[Raymond Souster]]'s volume, ''New Wave Canada: The Explosion in Canadian Poetry'' (1966).[[Louis Dudek]] and Michael Gnarowski describe the anthology's embracing of counterculture, including new ideas about sexuality and the role of women. Other anthologies began to focus specifically on women's writing, such as: *''[[Sisterhood Is Powerful|Sisterhood is Powerful]]'' (1970) edited by [[Robin Morgan]]; *''[http://msmagazine.com/blog/2018/05/15/no-masks-celebrating-landmark-anthology-womens-poetry-45-years-later/ No More Masks!]'' (1971) edited by [[Florence Howe]] and [[Ellen Bass]]; *''[https://www.pacificaradioarchives.org/recording/bc1738 The World Split Open]'' (1972) edited by [[Louise Bernikow]]; *''Psyche'' (1973) edited by Barbara Segnitz and Carol Rainey; *''New Poets, Women'' (1976) edited by Terry Wetherby; *''Contemporary Women Poets'' (1977) edited by Jennifer McDowell and Milton Leventhal; *''Open to Sun'' (1979) edited by Nora Jacquez Wieser; *''[[Lesbian Poetry: An Anthology|Lesbian Poetry]]'' (1982) edited by Elly Bulkin and [[Joan Larkin]]; *''Daughters of the Sun, Women of the Moon: Poetry by Black Canadian Women'' (1990) edited by Ann Wallace. Other anthologies created new canons of women's writing from the past, such as ''Black sister: poetry by black American women, 1746-1980'' (1981) edited by Erlene Stetson; or ''Writing Red: An Anthology of American Women Writers, 1930-1940'' (1987) edited by Paula Rabinowitz and Charlotte Nekola. Such anthologies "established solid ground for the communication and circulation of feminist ideas" in the American and Canadian Academies. Conferences also provided important spaces for feminists to share and discuss ideas about the possibilities of poetry: for example a key moment for Canadian feminist poetry was the "Women and words / Les femmes et les motes" conference in 1983.{{Cite journal|last=Beverley|first=Andrea|date=2017|title='Women and Words'|url=https://champlainsociety.utpjournals.press/findings-trouvailles/2017/11/women-and-words-1983-visual-traces|journal=The Champlain Society - Findings|volume=|pages=|via=}} The Vancouver convention brought together women writers, publishers, and booksellers to discuss the issues of the Canadian literary world, including gender inequity. === Modern Feminist Poetry in North America === One change in the writing of women poets after the 1960s and 1970s was the possibility of writing about women's lives and experiences. To give authority to women's voices, writers like [[Honor Moore]] and [[Judy Grahn|Judy Graun]] held workshops specifically for women in order to overcome women's inner critics exacerbated by sexism. These networks of mentorship sprang up in feminist communities, and in universities. The work at this time was focussing on "images of women," and this often meant broadening representations.{{Cite journal|last=Juhasz|first=Suzanne|date=1977|title=The critic as feminist: Reflections on women's poetry, feminism, and the art of criticism|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F00497878.1977.9978438|journal=Women's Studies|language=en|volume=5|issue=2|pages=113–127|doi=10.1080/00497878.1977.9978438|issn=0049-7878|via=}} This methodology eventually began to be criticised, however, because it failed to recognise the complications of violence embedded in the very structure of language.{{Cite journal|last=Sojka|first=Eugenia|date=2001|title=Canadian Feminist Writing and American Poetry|url=https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1128&context=clcweb|journal=CLCWeb: Comparative Literature and Culture|volume=3.2|pages=|via=}} Writers influenced by the [[avant-garde]] and by [[Language poets|L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetry]] sought to challenge the idea of language's neutrality. US feminist language poets like [[Lyn Hejinian|Lynn Hejinian]] or [[Susan Howe]], or Canadian writers like [[Daphne Marlatt]] looked back to the legacy of experimentalist modernists like [[Gertrude Stein]], or [[Mina Loy]], and also to diverse sources of inspiration like [[Denise Levertov]], [[Marguerite Duras]], [[Virginia Woolf]], [[Nicole Brossard]], [[Phyllis Webb]], [[Louky Bersianik]], and [[Julia Kristeva]]. They also reframed the language poetics from male mentors like [[Charles Olson]], [[Robert Creeley]], [[Gary Snyder]], or [[Allen Ginsberg]]. Poets also sought to intervene in spheres traditionally dominated by men. Take for example [[Eileen Myles]]' intervention into politics in her 1992 "Write-in Campaign for President."{{Cite web|url=http://www.eileenmyles.net/howto.htm|title=1992 Write-in Campaign for President:  Eileen Myles|website=www.eileenmyles.net|access-date=2018-09-26}} By the time of the 1990s, and the rise of [[intersectionality]] as a key feminist term, many feminist poets resisted the term "woman poet," because it suggested "too confining a collective identity." They also sought to undermine "the assumption that has sometimes structured feminist political organizing and even feminist literary publishing and criticism—that gender can be separated from race, ethnicity, class, and sexuality, and that white middleclass women first and foremost have the tools and the knowhow for the enterprise of analyzing gendered experience and literary production." Present day feminist poetry in North America holds space for a great variety of poets tackling identity, sexuality, and gender issues. Key writings in the recent past include [[Claudia Rankine]]'s careful skewering of race related [[microaggression]]s in ''Citizen,''{{Cite news|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2015/04/23/claudia-rankine-new-way-writing-about-race/|title='A New Way of Writing About Race'|last=Laird|first=Nick|work=The New York Review of Books|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} Dorothea Laskey's "ferocious confession" in Rome for example,{{Cite news|url=http://feministing.com/2014/07/31/feministing-readz-dorothea-laskys-rome/|title=Feministing Readz: Dorothea Lasky's Rome|work=Feministing|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} and Bhanu Kapil's challenge the violent inherent in structures of language and institutions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.metamute.org/editorial/articles/laying-down-banlieue|title=L(a)ying Down in the Banlieue {{!}} Mute|website=www.metamute.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} == Feminist Poetry in Western Europe == [[File:Elizabeth Barrett Browning - Project Gutenberg eText 16786.jpg|thumb|Elizabeth Barrett Browning]] === Feminist Writing after Mary Wollstonecraft === Eighteenth century advocate for women's rights [[Mary Wollstonecraft|Mary Wollstonecraf]]t (1797-1851), put great emphasis on the power of the poetic imagination as a liberator tool, and many nineteenth century British women writers were inspired by Wollstonecraft to use poetry to enter public debates about gender roles, poverty, and slavery.{{Cite journal|last=Wollstonecraft|first=Mary|date=1797|title="On Poetry and Our Relish for the Beauties of Nature"|url=|journal=Monthly Magazine|volume=April|pages=279–82|via=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/mary-wollstonecraft-shelley|title=Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} The verse-novel ''[[Aurora Leigh]]'' (1856) by [[Elizabeth Barrett Browning]] (1806-1861) is one such feminist work, which challenged a prevailing attitude that women's lives were incompatible with writing poetry.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/elizabeth-barrett-browning|title=Elizabeth Barrett Browning|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} ''Aurora Leigh'' had a very public impact, for example influencing the views of American social reformer [[Susan B. Anthony]] regarding the traditional roles of women, especially in relation to the tension between marriage and women's individuality.{{Cite book|title=Susan B. Anthony Rebel, Crusader, Humanitarian.|last=Lutz|first=Alma|publisher=Beacon Press|year=1959|isbn=|location=Boston|pages=}} === Late Nineteenth Century Feminist Poets in Britain === Often cited as an early feminist poet, [[Amy Levy]] (1861-1889) is described by writer [[Elaine Feinstein]] as the first modern Jewish woman poet.{{Cite book|title=Amy Levy : critical essays|last=Valman|first=Nadia|publisher=Ohio University Press|year=2010|isbn=9780821443071|location=Athens|pages=2}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/jewess-in-nineteenthcentury-british-literary-culture/A059306B33CC165DA9E8AC54E5816E4C|title=The Jewess in Nineteenth-Century British Literary Culture|last=Valman|first=Nadia|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780511484964|location=Cambridge|pages=119|language=en|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511484964}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/amy-levy|title=Amy Levy|last=Levy|first=Amy|date=2013-09-30|website=Amy Levy|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}} At the age of 13, Levy published her first poem in the feminist journal, the ''Pelican'', and she grew to maturity surrounded by writers and social reformers on the London scene of the era, such as [[Eleanor Marx]] and [[Olive Schreiner|Olive Schreiber]]. Though nothing is known for sure about Levy's sexual relationships, she is often thought of as a lesbian poet, though some critics have challenged affixing a sexual category to Levy.{{Cite book|title=Women’s Poetry, Late Romantic to Late Victorian: Gender and Genre, 1830–1900|last=Blain|first=Virginia|publisher=Macmillan|year=1999|isbn=|location=London|pages=138}} Levy's poems, however, are an early example of poetry that challenges [[Heteronormativity|heteronormative]] roles.{{Cite web|url=https://www.senatehouselibrary.ac.uk/blog/amy-levy-1861-1889-'minor-poet'|title=Amy Levy (1861-1889): a ‘Minor Poet’|last=|first=|date=|website=Senate House Library, University of London|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/953030317|title=Odd women? : spinsters, lesbians and widows in British women's fiction, 1850s-1930s|last=Emma,|first=Liggins,|publisher=|year=|isbn=9781526111654|location=Manchester|pages=4|oclc=953030317}} === Twentieth Century Feminist Poets in Britain === Levy is often thought of as prefiguring or representing an early version of the New Woman, a stereotypical image of an independent woman who often worked rather than relying on her menfolk, and was associated with [[Gender bender|gender bending]] and deviance.{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Dolores|date=1991|title=The "New Woman" as Prometheus: Women Artists Depict Women Smoking|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1358183|journal=Woman's Art Journal|volume=12|issue=1|pages=3–9|doi=10.2307/1358183}}{{Cite web|url=http://eprints.kingston.ac.uk/20661/|title=Amy Levy: her life, her poetry and the era of the new woman|last=Christine|first=Pullen,|date=2000|website=eprints.kingston.ac.uk|access-date=2018-09-17}} Historically, the end of the nineteenth and beginning of the twentieth century was an era of surplus women, who had to work to survive: by 1911, 77 per cent of women workers in the UK were single.{{Cite journal|last=Long|first=V.|last2=Marland|first2=H.|date=2009-01-01|title=From Danger and Motherhood to Health and Beauty: Health Advice for the Factory Girl in Early Twentieth-Century Britain|url=https://academic.oup.com/tcbh/article/20/4/454/1690021|journal=Twentieth Century British History|language=en|volume=20|issue=4|pages=454–481|doi=10.1093/tcbh/hwp027|issn=0955-2359}} Alongside the struggle of [[suffragette]]s campaigning for votes for women, many British feminist poets sought to emulate the example of Victorian women writers, often expressing their radical political beliefs through poetry.{{Cite web|url=https://britlitsurvey2.wordpress.com/2013/11/08/mary-wollstonecraft-influence-beyond-the-grave/|title=Mary Wollstonecraft: Influence Beyond the Grave|last=|first=|date=|website=British Literature 1700-1900, A Course Blog|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Often the writers were not professional poets, but wrote out of necessity, including satirical portraits of politicians, or writings from prison, as in ''Holloway Jingles'', a collection of writing from imprisoned women collated by the Glasgow Branch of the [[Women's Social and Political Union]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/54206569|title=Literature of the women's suffrage campaign in England|last=|first=|date=2004|publisher=Broadview Press|others=Nelson, Carolyn Christensen.|year=|isbn=1551115115|location=Peterborough, Ont.|pages=153|oclc=54206569}} === British Feminist Poets and Modernism === In the inter-war years, British women poets associated with modernism began to find themselves public figures, though their feminist ideas sometimes came into conflict with the literary establishment which remained a kind of "exclusive male club."{{Cite book|title=Women, Modernism and British Poetry, 1910–1939: Resisting Femininity|last=Dowson|first=Jane|publisher=Ash gate|year=2002|isbn=9780754604631|location=Burlington, VT|pages=}} Often these writers are difficult to categorize in relation to literary groups traditionally used, like the [[avant-garde]] or [[Modernism|modernists]]. This was also a period when American women poets living in Britain made an important contribution to the writing of the day: writers like [[H.D.]], [[Mina Loy]], and [[Amy Lowell]] all combined radical poetic content with experimentation of form, allowing them to explore feminist polemic and non-heteronormative sexualities in innovative new modes. Other British feminist poets of the time like [[Anna Wickham]], [[Charlotte Mew]], and [[Sylvia Townsend Warner]], receive less critical attention, but also sought to challenge and reevaluate tropes of femininity. === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry in Britain === During the 1960s, the Women's Liberation Movement in the UK had a great influence on the literary world.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bl.uk/sisterhood/articles/feminist-literature|title=Feminist literature|last=Sisterhood and After Research Team|first=|date=|website=The British Library|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Feminist publishers, [[Virago Press|Virago]] (founded in 1973), [[Onlywomen Press|Onlywomen]] (1974), The Women's Press (1978), and Sheba (1980), were established, alongside magazines like [https://www.bl.uk/spare-rib Spare Rib]. Like their counterparts in the US, British feminist editors in the 1970s and 80s created landmark anthologies of women's poetry, which foregrounded the variety and strength of women's writing. These included Lilian Mohin's ''One Foot on the Mountain'' (1979), [[Jeni Couzyn]]'s ''The Bloodaxe Book of Contemporary Women Poets'' (1985), Moira Ferguson's ''First Feminists: British Women Writers 1578-1799'' (1985), Kate Armstrong's ''Fresh Oceans'' (1989), Jude Brigley's ''Exchanges'' (1990), and Catherine Kerrigan's ''An Anthology of Scottish Women Poets'' (1991). '''References'''{{reflist}}{{Feminism|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Feminism and the arts]] [[Category:Poetry]] [[Category:Feminist literature]]

{{Infobox album | name = G.S.N.T. 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard | type = Studio album | artist = [[Saigon (rapper)|Saigon]] | cover = Saigon GSNT3.jpg | alt = | released = September 30, 2014 | recorded = 2013–2014 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = 51:32 | label = Squid Ink Squad | producer = Bananaz, Clev Trev, Deli Beats, DJ Corbett, [[DJ Premier]], Grande, Shuko | prev_title = [[The Greatest Story Never Told Chapter 2: Bread and Circuses]] | prev_year = 2012 | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Singles | name = G.S.N.T. 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard | type = Studio | single1 = Best Mistake | single1date = December 9, 2013 | single2 = Sinner's Prayer | single2date = July 29, 2014 | single3 = Nunya | single3date = August 19, 2014 }} }}
'''''G.S.N.T. 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard''''' is the third [[studio album]] by American [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist [[Saigon (rapper)|Saigon]]. The album was released on September 30, 2014, by Squid Ink Squad.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/gsnt-3-troubled-times-brian/id917472757|title=iTunes - Music - Gsnt 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard by Saigon|work=iTunes|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.30891/title.saigon-gsnt-3-the-troubled-times-of-brian-carenard-cover-art-tracklist-album-stream|title=Saigon "GSNT 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard" Cover Art, Tracklist & Album Stream|work=HipHopDX|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> The album features [[guest appearance]]s from [[Just Blaze]], Corbett, P. Jericho, [[Papoose (rapper)|Papoose]], [[Omar Epps]], [[Big Daddy Kane]], Curbside Hustle, [[Big Daddy Kane]], G. Martin, [[Memphis Bleek]], [[Lil Bibby]], [[Kool G Rap]] and Bryonn Bain. The album was supported by the singles "Best Mistake", "Sinner's Prayer" and "Nunya".
==Singles== On December 9, 2013, the album's first single "Best Mistake" featuring G. Martin was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/best-mistake-feat.-g.-martin/id775284628|title=iTunes - Music - Best Mistake (feat. G. Martin) - Single by Saigon|work=iTunes|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> On January 21, 2014, the music video was released for "Best Mistake" featuring G. Martin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rapradar.com/2014/01/21/new-video-saigon-x-g-martin-best-mistake/|title=New Video: Saigon x G. Martin “Best Mistake” - Rap Radar|work=Rap Radar|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> On July 29, 2014, the album's second single "Sinner's Prayer" featuring [[Papoose (rapper)|Papoose]] and [[Omar Epps]] was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/sinners-prayer-feat.-papoose/id903433613|title=iTunes - Music - Sinner's Prayer (feat. Papoose & Omar Epps) - Single by Saigon|work=iTunes|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> On August 4, 2014, the music video was released for "Sinner's Prayer" featuring Papoose and Omar Epps.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rapradar.com/2014/08/04/new-video-saigon-ft-papoose-x-omar-epps-sinners-prayer/|title=New Video: Saigon Ft. Papoose x Omar Epps “Sinner’s Prayer” - Rap Radar|work=Rap Radar|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> On August 19, 2014, the album's third single "Nunya" was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/nunya-single/id910819982|title=iTunes - Music - Nunya - Single by Saigon|work=iTunes|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> On September 28, 2014, the music video was released for "Nunya".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rapradar.com/2014/09/28/new-video-saigon-nunya/|title=New Video: Saigon “Nunya” - Rap Radar|work=Rap Radar|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref>
== Critical response == {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[HipHopDX]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name="HHDX">{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.2356/title.saigon-gsnt-3-the-troubled-times-of-brian-carenard|title=Saigon - GSNT 3: The Troubled Times Of Brian Carenard|work=HipHopDX|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]'' | rev2Score = 3/5 (L)<ref name="XXL">{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/reviews/2014/10/saigon-gsnt3-the-troubled-times-of-brian-carenard-album-review/|title=Saigon Delivers Potent Rhymes On 'G.S.N.T.3.: The Troubled Times Of Brian Carenard' - XXL|work=XXL|accessdate=3 October 2014}}</ref> }} ''G.S.N.T. 3: The Troubled Times of Brian Carenard'' received mixed reviews from [[music criticism|music critic]]s. Brandon Matthews of ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]'' gave the album an L, saying "True hip-hop fans will appreciate his new body of work as it counteracts the contemporary formula of heavy bass driven tracks that seem to have saturated radio. His features solidify his reputable status by having tracks with legends such as Big Daddy Kane, Kool G Rap, Papoose and even features Omar Epps (whom can actually rap!). He also grabs 2014 XXL Freshman Lil Bibby and fellow New York lyricist Memphis Bleek, who both shine on “Mechanical Animals (4 generations).” His beat selection identifies his desire to be a staple in the industry as opposed to a novelty, tapping the services of DJ Premier and Clev Trev."<ref name="XXL"/> Jay Balfour of [[HipHopDX]] gave the album three out of five stars, saying "While he’s developed himself into a recognizable Hip Hop pundit outside of his music, Saigon has struggled to maintain his voice inside of it. There’s consolation in the fact that he’s still a talented emcee, but he’s tried too much while staying safe at the same time. Saigon fans will find plenty to pick through on ''GSNT3'' but they may be the most alienated listeners as well, more aware than anyone that he is capable of better."<ref name="HHDX"/>
==Track listing== {{tracklist | extra_column = Producer(s)

Legal forms of gambling in the U.S. state of [[Maine]] include [[parimutuel wagering]] on [[horse races]], the [[Maine Lottery]], two [[casino]]s, and charitable gaming.
==Horse racing== [[Parimutuel wagering]] on [[harness racing]] is permitted at the state's two racetracks, [[Scarborough Downs]] in [[Scarborough, Maine|Scarborough]] and [[Bangor Raceway|Hollywood Casino Hotel & Raceway]] in [[Bangor, Maine|Bangor]]. Brief harness racing meets of up to nine days each also occur at nine [[agricultural fair]]s throughout the state, from July to October, with wagering allowed.<ref>{{cite report|title=Annual Report 2013|publisher=Maine State Harness Racing Commission|date=July 2014|url=http://digitalmaine.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1007&context=hrc_docs|page=50|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Through good times and bad, fairs racing on|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|author=Jenn Menendez|date=September 25, 2005|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F10CE0A8DE44AAE10&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}</ref>
Wagering is also offered at four [[off-track betting]] parlors around the state.<ref>{{cite web|title=Off-Track Betting|publisher=Maine State Harness Racing Commission|url=http://www.maine.gov/dacf/harnessracing/off-track_betting.shtml|accessdate=2017-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Off-track betting takes a piece, and a hit, from gambling in Maine|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|author=Dave Sherwood|date=May 3, 2017|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2017/05/03/off-track-betting-takes-piece-hit-gambling-maine/|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref>
==Casinos== Maine law allows two casinos: Hollywood Casino in Bangor and [[Oxford Casino]] in [[Oxford, Maine|Oxford]]. The two casinos had a total annual net gaming revenue of $132 million as of 2016.<ref>{{cite report|title=12th Annual Report|publisher=Maine Gambling Control Board|date=March 8, 2017|url=http://www.state.me.us/dps/GambBoard/annual-reports/Annual%20Final%20Report%202016.pdf|page=9|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref>
[[Slot machine]]s at horse tracks were approved in a statewide referendum in 2003, but were rejected by voters in the city of Scarborough, leading to Bangor having the only permitted casino.<ref>{{cite news|title=Track may seek out racino-friendly town|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|author=Justin Ellis|date=November 6, 2003|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F0FEAE82B8010DDCE&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}</ref> The casino in Oxford was approved by a statewide referendum in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Maine casino opponents give up recount challenge |newspaper=Portland Press Herald |date=December 14, 2010 |url= http://www.pressherald.com/news/casino-opponents-give-up-recount-challenge_2010-12-14.html |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> The racino law was amended the following year to allow [[table game]]s at Bangor.<ref>{{cite news|title=Maine casinos get ready for table games|newspaper=Associated Press|author=Clarke Canfield|date=November 25, 2011|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F13B436D44329EBD8&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}</ref>
==Charitable gaming== Maine law permits many types of community organizations to conduct various games of chance for fundraising purposes, including [[bingo (U.S.)|bingo]] (with prizes up to $400),<ref>{{cite web|title=Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, Chapter 13-A: Beano or bingo, Section 317: Rules and regulations|url=http://legislature.maine.gov/statutes/17/title17sec317.html|publisher=Maine Legislature|accessdate=2017-08-24}}</ref> [[raffle]]s (with prize values up to $75,000),<ref>{{cite web|title=Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, Chapter 62: Games of chance, Section 1837: Raffles|url=http://legislature.maine.gov/statutes/17/title17sec1837.html|accessdate=2017-08-24}}</ref> and card games (generally with a maximum bet of $1 per hand).<ref>{{cite web|title=Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, Chapter 62: Games of chance, Section 1835: Conduct games of chance|url=http://legislature.maine.gov/statutes/17/title17sec1837.html|accessdate=2017-08-24}}</ref>
==Indian gaming== State law permits Maine's four [[federally recognized tribes]] to conduct high-stakes bingo games with unlimited prize values.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maine Revised Statutes, Title 17, Chapter 13-A: Beano or bingo, Section 314-A: High-stakes beano|url=http://www.mainelegislature.org/legis/statutes/17/title17sec314-A.html|publisher=Maine Legislature|accessdate=2017-08-26}}</ref> The tribes do not have gaming rights that tribes in other states possess, because the [[Maine Indian Claims Settlement Act]] subjects the tribes' lands to state law, and excludes the [[Indian Gaming Regulatory Act]] from applying in the state.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Native American sovereignty in Maine|author=Stephen Brimley|journal=Maine Policy Review|date=2004|volume=13|issue=2|page=21|url=http://digitalcommons.library.umaine.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1201&context=mpr|accessdate=2017-08-26}}</ref>
==Lottery== The [[Maine Lottery]] offers [[scratchcard|scratch-off]] and drawing games, including the multi-state [[Powerball]] and [[Mega Millions]] games.
==See also== * [[Gambling in the United States]]

{{Multiple issues| {{No footnotes|date=June 2016}} {{One source|date=June 2016}} {{globalize|date=December 2009}} }} A '''[[gossip]] columnist''' is someone who writes a '''gossip column''' in a [[newspaper]] or [[magazine]], especially a [[gossip magazine]]. Gossip columns are material written in a light, informal style, which relates the gossip columnist's opinions about the personal lives or conduct of [[Celebrity|celebrities]] from [[show business]] ([[film|motion picture]] [[movie star]]s, [[theater]], and [[television]] actors), [[politician]]s, [[professional sports]] stars, and other [[wealth]]y people or public figures. Some gossip columnists broadcast segments on [[radio programming|radio]] and [[television program|television]].
The columns mix factual material on arrests, divorces, marriages and pregnancies, obtained from official records, with more speculative gossip stories, [[rumor]]s, and [[innuendo]] about romantic relationships, affairs, and purported personal problems.
Gossip columnists have a reciprocal relationship with the celebrities whose private lives are splashed about in the gossip column's pages. While gossip columnists sometimes engage in (borderline) [[defamation|defamatory]] conduct, spreading innuendo about alleged [[Morality|immoral]] or illegal conduct that can injure celebrities' reputations, they also are an important part of the "Star System" publicity machine that turns movie actors and musicians into celebrities and [[superstar]]s that are the objects of the public's obsessive attention and interest. The [[press agent|publicity agents]] of celebrities often provide or "leak" information or rumors to gossip columnists to publicize the celebrity or their projects, or to counteract "bad press" that has recently surfaced about their conduct.
==Libel and defamation== While gossip columnists’ "bread and butter" is rumor, innuendo, and allegations of scandalous behavior, there is a fine line between legally acceptable spreading of rumor and the making of defamatory statements, which can provoke a lawsuit. Newspaper and magazine editorial policies normally require gossip columnists to have a source for all of their allegations, to protect the publisher against lawsuits for [[defamation]] (libel).
In the United States, celebrities or public figures can sue for libel if their private lives are revealed in gossip columns and they believe that their reputation has been defamed — that is, exposed to hatred, contempt, ridicule, or [[money|pecuniary]] loss. Gossip columnists cannot defend against libel claims by arguing that they merely repeated, but did not originate the defaming rumor or claim; instead, a columnist must prove that the allegedly defaming statement was truthful, or that it was based on a reasonably reliable source.
In the mid-1960s, rulings by the [[United States Supreme Court]] made it harder for the media to be sued for libel in the U.S. The court ruled that libel only occurred in cases where a publication printed falsehoods about a celebrity with “reckless disregard” for the truth. A celebrity suing a newspaper for libel must now prove that the paper published the falsehood with actual [[malice (legal term)|malice]], or with deliberate knowledge that the statement was both incorrect and defamatory.
Moreover, the court ruled that only factual misrepresentation is libel, not expression of opinion. Thus if a gossip columnist writes that they “...think that Celebrity X is an idiot,” the columnist does not face a risk of being sued for libel. On the other hand, if the columnist invents an allegation that “...Celebrity X is a wife beater,” with no supporting source or evidence, the celebrity can sue for libel on the grounds that their reputation was defamed.
There is however circumstances where gossip columnist may not be fact checking the information they are receiving from their sources before publishing their stories. Not to mention that there are gossip columnist that are not reputable themselves to be posting articles about celebrities. As a result of this there is a chance that there are stories that have been publish that could lead to the defamation of celebrities.
==History== [[File:Louella-Parsons-1937.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Louella Parsons]] (1937)]] The first gossip columnist, dominating the 1930s and 40s, was [[Walter Winchell]], who used political, entertainment, and social connections to mine information and rumors, which he then either published in his column ''On Broadway'', or used for trade or blackmail, to accumulate more power. He became "the most feared journalist" of his era.
In [[Hollywood]]'s "[[Classical Hollywood cinema|golden age]]" in the 1930s and 1940s, gossip columnists were courted by the [[movie studio]]s, so that the studios could use gossip columns as a powerful publicity tool. During this period, the major film studios had "stables" of contractually obligated actors, and the studios controlled nearly all aspects of the lives of their movie stars. From the 1930s through the 1950s, the two best-known - and competing - Hollywood gossip columnists were [[Hedda Hopper]] and [[Louella Parsons]].
Well-timed [[News leak|leaks]] about a star's purported romantic adventures helped the studios to create and sustain the public's interest in the studios' star actors. As well, the movie studios' publicity agents acted as unnamed "well-informed inside sources" who provided misinformation and rumors to counteract whispers about celebrity secrets — such as [[homosexuality]] or an [[Legitimacy (family law)|out-of-wedlock]] child — that could have severely damaged not only the reputation of the movie star in question, but the movie star's box office viability.
Having fallen into ill-repute after the heyday of Hopper and Parsons, gossip columnists saw a comeback in the 1980s. Today, many mainstream magazines such as ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' which would once have considered the idea of hiring gossip columnists to pen articles to have been beneath their stature, have sections titled "People" or "Entertainment". These mainstream gossip columns provide a light, chatty glimpse into the private lives and misadventures of the rich and famous. At the other end of the journalism spectrum, there are entire publications that deal primarily in gossip, rumor, and innuendo about celebrities, such as the [[tabloid (newspaper format)|'red-top' tabloids]] in the UK and [[Gossip magazine|celebrity 'tell-all' magazines]].
==Notable gossip columnists== [[File:Cindy Adams by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Cindy Adams]] (April 2007)]] [[File:Michael Musto cropped by David Shankbone.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Michael Musto]] (March 2007)]]
Notable gossip columnists include: {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| *[[Cindy Adams]] *[[Jani Allan]] *[[Flo Anthony]] *[[Army Archerd]] *[[Rona Barrett]] *[[Marilyn Beck]] *[[A.J. Benza]] *Jamie Foster Brown *[[Milly Cangiano]] *[[Ted Casablanca]] *Janet Charlton *[[Claudia Cohen]] *[[Mike Connolly (columnist)|Mike Connolly]] *[[Giles Coren]] *[[Ana Marie Cox]] *[[Nigel Dempster]] *[[Matt Drudge]] *Shirley Eder *[[Jinx Falkenburg]] *[[Jimmy Fidler]] *[[Luke Ford (blogger)|Luke Ford]] *[[Sheilah Graham Westbrook]] *[[Lloyd Grove]] *[[Ian Halperin]] *[[Tanya Hart]] *[[David Hartnell]] *[[Courtney Hazlett]] *[[Perez Hilton]] *[[Hedda Hopper]] *[[Arianna Huffington]] *[[Micah Jesse]] *[[Shia Kapos]] *[[Dorothy Kilgallen]] *[[Irv Kupcinet]] *[[Frances Lynn]] *[[Isabel Mallon]] as "Bab" (1880s–90s) *[[Elsa Maxwell]] *[[Florabel Muir]] *Susan Mulcahy *[[Michael Musto]] *[[Louella Parsons]] *[[Drew Pearson (journalist)|Drew Pearson]] *[[Rex Reed]] *[[Sidney Skolsky]] *[[Liz Smith (journalist)|Liz Smith]] *[[Adela Rogers St. Johns]] *[[Jimmy Starr]] *[[Ed Sullivan]] *[[Ian Ortega Uganda]] *[[Mike Walker (columnist)|Mike Walker]] *[[Jeannette Walls]] *[[Earl Wilson (columnist)|Earl Wilson]] *[[Walter Winchell]] *[[Mila Ximénez]] }}
==Columns not named for a columnist== Gossip columns that are not named after a specific columnist, along with the media source, include:
* ''[[The 3AM Girls|3am]]'' — ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', a [[British newspaper]]. * ''[[Access Hollywood]]'' — a [[Broadcast syndication|syndicated television]] program{{Clarify|date=December 2009|reason=this editor not quite sure this "gossip column" article should include non-newspaper/magazine items}} * ''[[Bizarre (gossip column)|Bizarre]]'' — ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', a [[London]] newspaper * ''[[Page Six]]'' — ''[[New York Post]]'', a [[New York City]] newspaper * ''Inside New York'', in New York ''Post'', New York City newspaper * ''[[Inside the Beltway (gossip column)|Inside the Beltway]]'' — ''[[The Washington Times]]'', a [[Washington, D.C.]] newspaper * ''[[Off the Record (gossip column)|Off the Record]]'' — ''[[The New York Observer]]'', a New York newspaper * ''[[Vegas Confidential (gossip column)|Vegas Confidential]]'' — ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'', a [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] newspaper

{{Music of Haiti}} '''Haitian hip hop''' or '''rap kreyòl''', is music originating from [[Haiti]] and sung by artists of Haitian origin.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wildermuth |first=Erin |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/apr/21/us-hip-hop-haiti-musical-fusion-cultural-conquest/ |title=American hip-hop in Haiti: Musical fusion or cultural conquest? |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-04-21 |accessdate=2014-02-25}}</ref> Often, hardcore beats are used while the artist raps in [[Haitian Creole]]. Rap kreyòl has been part of Haitian culture since the early 1980s with groups such as Original Rap Staff, King Posee, Rap Kreyòl S.A., Masters of Haiti, Fighters, Blackdo, Fam-Squad, Supa Deno, Prince Berlin and Muzion attaining prominence, but lately has become very popular with Haitian youth.<ref name="google156">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/booksid=_7NIe_I298MC&pg=PA156 |title=Caribbean Currents: Caribbean Music from Rumba to Reggae |author=Manuel, Peter with Kenneth Bilby, Michael Largey |page=156 |year=2006 |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> Another notable group from the 1990s is Black Leaders. The impact of Black Leaders and its members is lasting. Though known primarily for his role in Black Leaders, Don Roy is still an active contributor to Haitian music across many genres. Since the peak of his notoriety, Don Roy has chosen to create in other genres. While still working in a production capacity in genres such as Rap Kreyòl and Reggae, Don Roy has chosen to create and work with prominent artists of the modern roots/Rasin movement.<ref>http://www.ambafrance-ht.org/L-Institut-francais-chaque-jour</ref>
Many Haitian rap artists have had rough childhoods and difficult living conditions producing rappers who address socio-economic topics in their lyrics.<ref name="google156"/> Though similar to mainstream American [[hip hop]] in that materialistic imagery is portrayed or lyricized, the negative aspects of less fortunate Haitian society, such as topics concerning slum life, gang warfare, the drug trade, and poverty, are much more common.
The most well-known exports of Haitian hip hop are two members of the legendary [[Grammy Award]]-winning hip hop group, the [[Fugees]], [[Wyclef Jean]] and his cousin [[Pras Michel]]. Most recently, Christopher ''Freedom'' Laroche released his inspirational debut album ''Liberation 1804'', Kerns (Mr OK) Olirice released his first EP (Men Mwen) while acts like [[Barikad Crew]], Rockfam, Brimad, Topson, Chale Republic, Pick Up Click, BriganDie, Team Lobey, Dezod Beats and G Bobby Bon Flo, Steves J. Bryan have gained popularity among the Haitian population. However, the godfather of hip hop in Haiti is the late [[Master Dji]], who not only released the first Haitian rap song in the early 1980s, formed the group Rap Kreyòl S.A., but was also the first Haitian DJ and also influential in encouraging other young Haitians such as Supa Deno, DJ Fanfan and DJ Live to become rappers, [[Disc jockey|DJ]]s, and [[B-boying|breakdancers]].
